I've seen this:

  $config = config('some_config.settings');
  $config->set('some_setting', $form_state['values']['some_setting']);
  $config->set('another_setting', $form_state['values']['another_setting']);
  $config->set('yet_another_setting', $form_state['values']['yet_another_setting']);
  $config->save();

...but also this:

  $config = config('some_config.settings');
  $config
    ->set('some_setting', $form_state['values']['some_setting'])
    ->set('another_setting', $form_state['values']['another_setting'])
    ->set('yet_another_setting', $form_state['values']['yet_another_setting'])
    ->save();

Are these both acceptable?
Yes, if the return value of the method (set()) is an object. The following method needs to be valid for the returned object.

Config::set() returns $this, which is a pointer to itself (a config object), so you can chain calls to the method: https://api.backdropcms.org/api/backdrop/core%21includes%21config.inc/function/Config%3A%3Aset/1
Yes, I'm aware of how it works and why ...just asking about the code formatting (DX for less experienced developers or code tinkerers)

...I've found my answer here (did not know that there was a dedicated page for OOP): https://www.drupal.org/docs/develop/standards/object-oriented-code#chaining

In the case where you have a fluid interface for a class, and the code spans more than one line, the method calls should be indented with 2 spaces:
...so the second format is indeed allowed.
You question "Are these both acceptable?" was not clear what you meant.
Yeah, I see what you mean ...I thought that the thread topic would provide context :sweat_smile:
Sorry about that. I didn't even read the topic. :frown:
Only ever apologize if you've actually done something wrong ...and even then, it usually is not necessary when in the company of friends :slight_smile:
